data.title: This Week in History, Sept. 11: Carol Burnett turns her dysfunctional past into TV comedy gold
data.meta_description: The Carol Burnett Show made its fans laugh with film parodies, slapstick humour, and great outfits for 11 seasons starting Sept. 11, 1967
data.text:
The Carol Burnett Show made its fans laugh with film parodies, slapstick humour, and great outfits for 11 seasons starting Sept. 11, 1967.

Article content

While The Carol Burnett Show’s ratings were never good enough to make it into the Top 10, it was a beloved hour of television comedy for fans in Canada and the U.S.

For anyone unfamiliar with the show and its appeal, here is a great description by Vancouver Sun arts critic Lloyd Dykk.

“The Carol Burnett Show was an hour’s truce even for squabbling families who gathered in front of the TV set to laugh themselves silly over a far more dysfunctional family as Eunice (what a name) and Mama (the divine Vicky Lawrence) shrieked at each other over the Monopoly board like demented banshees while Harvey Korman, God bless him, sat frozen and glowering in his lay-z boy chair.”

Article content

First broadcast on CBS on Sept. 11, 1967, The Carol Burnett Show ran for 11 seasons before concluding with a two-hour finale on March 29, 1978. Each televised show was edited together from two performances in front of a live audience.

The show turned Burnett into a television superstar.

At the time, few knew Burnett’s personal story. Both her parents were alcoholics. When they divorced, Burnett was sent to live with her grandmother in a studio apartment in a poor part of Hollywood.

Burnett translated her dysfunctional past into comedy gold on television.

“The meticulously structured, musical-comedy program became one of the last, and one of the finest prime-time variety shows to link the modern television age with Tin Pan Alley and the Golden Ages of motion pictures and television,” the Museum of Broadcast Communications said about Burnett’s show.

“The show brought Carol Burnett’s working-class persona into a unique relationship with her audience.”

In September 2008, Burnett visited The Orpheum where a sold-out audience saw a performance that included the funniest clips from the TV show. Most of it featured Burnett in an unscripted Q&A with fans — a longer version of what preceded her TV show.

“The crowd adored her, she said she loved being here, and for once you didn’t question the homilies of a visiting star: She seems utterly genuine,” Dykk said about Burnett’s show. “She looked great too and wore a smart red suit.”

Costumes and outfits were always a stand-out part of the show thanks to the great Bob Mackie, the fashion designer who made thousands of outfits during the 11 seasons.

Perhaps the most famous was for the skit Went with the Wind!, a parody of Gone with the Wind. Burnett played Starlett O’Hara (aka Scarlett) who descends a staircase in a dress made out of drapes with curtain rods for shoulder pads and a valance for a hat. The dress is on display at the Smithsonian Institution.

Another notable character was Nora Desmond, a former silent movie star assisted by Max, the loyal but controlling butler played by Korman. It was a parody of Sunset Boulevard, a movie starring Desmond as a former film star who lives in a fantasy world about making a comeback.

There were also numerous occasions when performers broke out of character. One of the biggest culprits was Tim Conway, who regularly ad-libbed lines to make Korman laugh. Even when he didn’t succeed, the contorted expressions on Korman’s face created genuine, unscripted moments that fans could connect with.

One of many distinctive elements in the show came at its end. After the song I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together, Burnett would tug at her left ear which was a secret message of love to her grandmother who had raised her. Even after her grandma’s death, Burnett kept tugging at her ear to end the show.
